questions.text: A man comes to emergency with stab injury to left flank. He has stable vitals. What would be the next step in management(AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Main thing which we look in case of penetrating injury is hemodynamic stability. If patient is hemodynamically unstable then patient needs to be taken for emergency exploratory laparotomy. If patient is hemodynamically stable with no signs of peritonitis or evisceration then we need to subject the patient to CECT to get a better understanding of the any significant intra abdominal injury. • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is done in cases of blunt abdominal trauma when FAST results are equivocal. DPL gives the idea of intra peritoneal fluid or blood collection and helps surgeon to make a decision whether to operate the person or not . • Laparotomy is done in hemodynamically unstable patients, those with signs of peritonitis or any evisceration of organ. • Laparoscopy has no role in acute trauma.

choices.text: Continue the conservative treatment and take subsequent measures on monitoring the patient

questions.text: A 30-years old gentleman after sustaining road traffic accident present in emergency with BP 100/60 mmHg, Pulse 120 per min and CT scan shows splenic laceration at inferior border. after 2 units of blood transfusion, patients conditions are: BP 120/70 mmHg and pulse 84/min; the next line of management is: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In this case scenario patient has suffered a splenic laceration due to penetrating injury and patient is hemodynamically stable after giving 2 units of blood. As patient is hemodynamically stable we can put the patient on conservative management. Conservative management means we need to put the patient on serial abdominal examinations, monitor abdominal girth, record BP and pulse at serial intervals and repeat CT Abdomen and pelvis every 24 hours if needed. if anytime during the conservative management if patient becomes hemodynamically unstable then operative managent is preferred. Laparotomy, splenoraphy and splenectomy are undertaken if the patient is hemodynamically unstable. Only role of X-ray abdomen standing in a patient of blunt abdominal trauma is to rule out any hollow viscera perforation.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a massive injury to proximal duodenum, head of pancreas and distal common bile duct. Patient is H.stable. The procedure of choice in this patient should be: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pancreas and second part of duodenum are closely related to each other as many times an injury involving one also tends to involve the other . If a patient suffers from a massive injury involving proximal duodenum, pancreatic head and distal common bile duct, we are left with an only option to carry out a pancreaticoduodenectomy or a whipple’s procedure in such patients. Option A C and D are not used for the treatment of pancreatic injury. If there is massive injury to pancreatic head with sparing of duodenum we have to go for duodenum preserving pancreatic head resection or Beger’s Procedure.

choices.text: Endotracheal intubation + IPPV + pleural fluid aspiration

questions.text: Treatment of acutely developing massive left sided hemo-thorax in a young male after an accident is: (AIIMS Nov 13)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) this patient is developing hemothorax of left side which over a period of time will compromise the expansion of the lungs and will lead to hypoxia. In order to prevent this we need to go for tube thoracotomy in which we drain the excess blood in the thoracic cavity thus allowing the lungs to expand. Option A is wrong as strapping of chest will not help in hemothorax in anyway. Option C is treatment of choice for severe flail chest. Option D is wrong as we do not follow conservative management for haemothorax.

choices.text: Full dose of Human tetanus Ig

questions.text: What will be the appropriate management of a patient with a clean wound over forearm with slight loss of tissue. he has received, tetanus toxoid 12 years back: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Limb salvage can be done in all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) if there is a vascular injury then patient will have ischemic injury to the distal part and if the distal limb becomes gangrenous we have to do an amputation we can not salvage that limb. Remember indications for amputation are 3D: Dead, Deadly and dead loss. If there is a nerve injury or bone injury or a muscle injury we can still salvage the limb.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a principle followed in the management of missile injuries? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) MANAGEMENT OF MISSILE INJURIES • In limb wounds, exploration is followed by thorough wound excision, after which, with very few exceptions, the wound should be left open. • Foreign matter should be removed from the wound. • Dead muscle that does not bleed or contract, is mushy in consistency or has an unhealthy colour must be excised. These criteria comprise is the ‘4 Cs’ for muscle excision (Colour, Contractility, Consistency, Capillary bleeding) • Bone shattered by high-energy transfer will in many instances still have attachment to periosteum or muscle. • Such fragments must not be discarded. Loss of bone may result in malunion (e.g. shortening) or nonunion

questions.text: In resection of muscle with history of trauma/crush injury, resection depends on: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B & C) Dead muscle that does not bleed or contract, is mushy in consistency or has an unhealthy colour must be excised. These criteria comprise is the ‘4 Cs’ for muscle excision (Colour, Contractility, Consistency, Capillary bleeding)

questions.text: During reconstruction of an amputated limb which of the following is done first? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) SEQUENCE OF REPAIR IN HAND INJURIES (BE FAN OF VEINS) • Bone shortening and stabilization or fixation • Extensor tendon repair • Flexor tendon repair • Arterial anastomoses • Nerve repair • Venous anastomosis • Skin/wound closure

questions.text: In crush injuries of hand the greatest priority is given to repair of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D-In any type of crush injuries of hand,vascular repair is given the highest priority as without vascular supply the hand may go into gangrene.

questions.text: Amputated digits are preserved in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The amputated digits are cleansed under saline solution ,wrapped in saline moistened gauze, and placed in a plastic bag The plastic bag containing the part is then placed on (not packed in) a bed of ice in a suitable container The amputated part should never be immersed in non physiological solution such as antiseptics or alcohol.

questions.text: After splenectomy for trauma, the optimal timing for administration of the pneumococcal vaccine is on postoperative day:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In patients who have unanticipated splenectomy (i.e., trauma), administering the pneumococcal vaccine immediately postoperatively will result in a much higher likelihood of the need for revaccination. The optimal timing is 14 days after surgery. Furthermore, in patients undergoing planned splenectomy, those who received the vaccine less than 14 days before surgery were more likely to need revaccination. However, in the trauma population many patients are lost to follow-up and some surgeons elect to administer the appropriate vaccines before discharge Pneumococcal vaccine needs to be repeated every 5 to 7 years

questions.text: A male came to the ER after car accident. He had dyspnea and chest pain with ecchymosis on anterior chest wall. On examination, pulse -120/min, BP-80/50mmHg, breaths sounds were decreased on left side, JVP was raised and tympanic note was present on percussion. Pelvis and extremities were normal. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-In tension pneumothorax, Breath sounds will be decreased due to compression of lung by air in pleural cavity.Tympanic note on percussion will be heared due to air and obstructive shock can result in hypotension with increased pulse rate and raised JVP. Option B-Massive hemothorax will be dull on percussion. Option C-Cardiac tamponade will not cause tympanic note. Option D-In case of hydropneumothorax ,dull note will be heard on percussion due to fluid.

questions.text: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hemorrhagic shock are classified into following classes:- class 1-<15% blood loss class 2-15-30% blood loss class 3-30-40% blood loss class 4->40% blood loss

questions.text: A patient came to ER after RTA. He is conscious, could speak in single word sentences. RR-40/min and BP-70/40 mm Hg. What will be your next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Intubating the patient won't help unless you remove air from pleural cavity. Option B-Urgent fluid infusion is not the first step as according to ABCDE,airway and breathing should be controlled first followed by circulation. Option C-There is no time for Chest X-Ray in such emergency condition. Option D-The given case scenario indicates tension pneumothorax as patient is having respiratory distress along with hypotension.Next step in case of tension pneumothorax is Needle insertion in 5th ICS along mid axillary line.

questions.text: Patient presented to emergency after RTA with multiple rib fractures. He is conscious, speaking single words. On examination, respiratory rate was 40/min and BP was 90/40 mmHg. What is immediate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The increased respiratory rate with hypotension,along with history of multiple rib fractures suggests diagnosis of tension pneumothorax. Option A-Urgent IV fluid administration is not the 1st step as airway and breathing should be controlled prior to circulation. Option B-Intubate the patient won't help as lung is collapsed by air in pleural cavity. Option C-X-ray is not done as patient is unstable. Option D-Inserting Needle in 5th intercostal space is the immediate next step in case of tension pneumothorax to remove excess air followed by ICD tube in 5th intercostal space.

questions.text: Arrange the following types of renal injury in order from lower to higher grade: A. Subcapsular hematoma B. Hematomas contained in Gerota’s fascia C. Avulsion of the pedicle D. Shattered kidney
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Renal injury in order from lower to higher grade is as follows:- A. Subcapsular hematoma B. Hematomas contained in Gerota’s fascia C. Avulsion of the pedicle D. Shattered kidney

questions.text: 26 year old man with RTA, complicated with pelvic fracture and is transfused blood. Within a few hours, patient developed fever , oliguria , hypotension. CVP is normal but there is bleeding from the site of IV line and through the ryles tube. What is the most common diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-In fat embolism,fever and oliguria will not be seen Breathing difficulty & petechiae will be seen. Option B-Blood transfusion reaction can cause fever,oliguria due to kidney damage,hypotension and bleeding from I.V. line. Option C-Adrenal insufficiency won't cause bleeding from I.V. line. Option D-Hemorrhagic shock usually don't cause fever.In fact,patient has cold clammy skin.

questions.text: Young male with RTA and poor GCS, was intubated, having normal NCCT, no cervical injury or pelvic fracture. FAST is negative. Likely Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CT is normal in cases of DAI(diffuse axonal injury). MRI will show small punctate pin point bleeding spots at grey white matter junction.

questions.text: Sequence of arrangement of following in RTA is? A. Cervical spine stabilization B. Intubation C. IV cannula D. Vital measurements
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ABCDE of trauma care : - 1.Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) 2.Breathing and ventilation assessment ( maintain adequate oxygenation,example by intubation) 3.Circulation assessment (check vitals and Control Hemorrhage):- Two wide bore (14 G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for iv fluid resuscitation 4.Disability assessment:-This is most commonly assessed by the Glasgow coma scale 5.Exposure ,with environmental control
